original.definition: spread out or open from a closed or folded state

sememes.reasoning: The definition 'spread out or open from a closed or folded state' explicitly describes a transition in the physical state of an object.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' in the verb frame is the entity initiating and performing the action of unfolding.
The 'something' in the verb frame is the object that undergoes the change from a folded/closed state to an open/spread-out state.
The 'PP' (prepositional phrase) in this frame typically specifies the location where the unfolding action occurs, making it a circumstantial participant.

Evidentiality.reasoning: The act of unfolding is a directly observable physical action.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, describing an action or event.

Modality.reasoning: The presence of 'Somebody' as the agent implies the action is carried out with strong will and intention.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of unfolding itself is neutral; its positive or negative sentiment depends on the context.

Volitionality.reasoning: The verb frame 'Somebody unfold...' explicitly indicates a volitional agent performing the action.

Confidence.reasoning: The verb describes a definite occurrence of the action.

Iterativity.reasoning: The lexeme 'unfold' describes a single, completed event of changing state, not a repetitive action.

sememes.reasoning: verb_property 'physical_state.n.01' is not a valid synset in NLTK.

candidates.description: (Middle Ages) one of the four fluids in the body whose balance was believed to determine your emotional and physical state (gloss match)
a datum about some physical state that is presented to a user by a meter or similar instrument (gloss match)
one of the minimum number of parameters needed to describe the state of a physical system (gloss match)

(philosophy) the philosophical theory that formal (logical or mathematical) statements have no meaning but that its symbols (regarded as physical entities) exhibit a form that has useful applications (gloss match)
the entire body of physically fit civilians eligible by law for military service; ; --United States Constitution (gloss match)
United States comic actor in silent films; he used physical danger as a source of comedy (1893-1971) (gloss match)
a definite stable energy that a physical system can have; used especially of the state of electrons in atoms or molecules (gloss match)
the state of being an isomer; the complex of chemical and physical phenomena characteristic of isomers (gloss match)
the condition of living or the state of being alive (gloss match)
the state of being physically constrained (gloss match)
(physical chemistry) a distinct state of matter in a system; matter that is identical in chemical composition and physical state and separated from other material by the phase boundary (gloss match)

(physical chemistry) a fourth state of matter distinct from solid or liquid or gas and present in stars and fusion reactors; a gas becomes a plasma when it is heated until the atoms lose all their electrons, leaving a highly electrified collection of nuclei and free electrons (gloss match)

sememes.corrected_reasoning: LLM suggestion: The invalid 'physical_state.n.01' refers to the state of an object's physical arrangement. 'configuration.n.01' ('an arrangement of parts or elements in a particular form, figure, or group') perfectly captures this concept, especially for a verb like 'unfold' which describes a change in arrangement.
